results.title: My time again - Richard Burton
results.brief_description: Richard Burton talks about how he became an actor, and discusses the art of acting for stage and screen with Michael Elwyn who is, like Burton, a Welsh actor who moved towards professional acting while a member of the Oxford University Dramatic Society.

results.title: My tiger's eyes
results.creator_credit: Teck Tan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: The conservative anti-Communist era of the 1950’s, the Cold War and the “Reds under the bed” - in Sydney, Australia, a young Chinese boy grows up and the Irish/Australian neighbours suspect his family might very well be Communists. The paranoia of the O’Hallorans takes on a comic twist when the boy’s Uncle Walter arrives in the country. A refugee from the Chinese Communist Revolution, the O’Hallorans take him for a Communist spy instead. Seen through the not-so-innocent eyes of 10 year-old Robert Ah Louey, the film captures the social attitudes of the 1950’s, the cultural nuances of neighbours on either side of the fence, and in the process saying something of what it was like being Chinese in Australia during the 50’s. Cast includes Adam Gungor (Robert), Terry Woo (Uncle Walter), Genevieve Mooy (Dolores O’Halloran), Peter Whitford (Jack O’Halloran). (Awards: Special Prize, ATOM Awards, 1993; Finalist, Best Fiction Category and EAC Award, Sydney Film Festival, 1992; Nominated Best Short Film AFI Awards, 1992)

results.title: My Sweet Little Village = Vesnicko Ma Strediskova
results.creator_credit: Jiri Menzel, Jan Suster and Barrandov Studios
results.brief_description: My Sweet Little Village examines with simple affection the affairs - comic, sad, quirky and downright ordinary - of a village collective farm in Czechoslovakia. The story begins and ends with a marvellous comic pair - truckie’s offsider, Otek, and his long suffering workmate. There is not a solitary political utterance to be heard, but the film still manages to subtly convey the graft and corruption permeating every level of Czech society.

results.title: My Survival as an Aboriginal
results.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_primary.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_primary.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
description_for_label: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.

results.title: My survival as an Aboriginal
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions
results.brief_description: After being forced from their tribal grounds, the Murrowarri were dumped onto a tiny reserve on the fringe of a white town. In this film Essie Coffey, black activist and musician, shows the conflicts of living as an Aboriginal under white domination. This film is part of her effort to make her community proud of their black identity while struggling to survive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions

results.title: My survival as a deviant
results.brief_description: Director Toby Zoates takes his camera to the squats of inner Sydney in an attempt to ascertain who the real deviants of society are - those who choose to do things their own way, or those that try to stop them. Utilising the cinema verite style and a punk soundtrack, he interviews a cross-section of people affected by issues such as unemployment and drugs, and examines the tactics those disenfranchised by societal pressures use to survive. This documentary, shot during Malcolm Fraser’s reign as Prime Minister, looks at the mundane reality of life for many young people, and aims to persuade viewers to take political action against a system that is seen to oppress individuality and demonise non-conformist behaviour. Filmed around Pyrmont, Kings Cross, and Chippendale.

results.title: My special family
results.creator_credit: Erin Wilson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Erin Wilson pays tribute to her special family, a family who have taught her all about life. From her family, Erin has learnt responsibility, empathy, the realities of life and death and, most importantly, love and friendship. Here she pays tribute to the members of this special family.

results.title: My So-Called Life
results.brief_description: The life of a 15 year-old high school student, whose angst-ridden journey through adolescence, friendship, parents, and life teaches her what it means to grow up.

constellations_other.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes

results.title: My sky, my home = Langitku rumahku
results.brief_description: At the centre of this film is an unlikely friendship between two twelve year old boys - Andri is from a wealthy family and Gempol is from a poor family. Both are deprived in different ways, Andri of the love and attention from his father, Gempol the chance of education and opportunities in life. A bond develops between them and they set out to find Gempol’s displaced family. The central theme focusing on the vitality and resourcefulness of the poor embellished with oblique political jokes did not find favour with it’s Indonesian distributors who withdrew it from cinemas on the grounds that it was uncommercial! The ensuing press controversy in Indonesia brought it to world wide attention. Indonesian dialogue with English subtitles. For use with secondary school students and adults, this film comes with a bibliography and study notes.
